xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This research was supported by the Ratchadapiseksomphot Endowment Fund 2016 of Chulalongkorn University under the Climate Change and Disaster Management Cluster (CCDM 59-CU). Thanks are also extended to T. Pailoplee for the preparation of the draft manuscript. I thank the Publication Counseling Unit (PCU), Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, and the Office of Research Affairs, Chulalongkorn University, for the critical review and improved English. I acknowledge the thoughtful comments and suggestions by Thomas Braun (associate editor), anonymous reviewers, and Raphael Bissen that enhanced the quality of this manuscript significantly.

organization.$: Morphology of Earth Surface and Advanced Geohazards in Southeast Asia Research Unit (MESA RU)

head.citation-title: Precursory seismic quiescence along the Sumatra-Andaman subduction zone: past and present
head.abstracts: © 2016, Springer Science+Business Media Dordrecht.In this study, the seismic quiescence prior to hazardous earthquakes was analyzed along the Sumatra-Andaman subduction zone (SASZ). The seismicity data were screened statistically with mainshock earthquakes of Mw ≥ 4.4 reported during 1980–2015 being defined as the completeness database. In order to examine the possibility of using the seismic quiescence stage as a marker of subsequent earthquakes, the seismicity data reported prior to the eight major earthquakes along the SASZ were analyzed for changes in their seismicity rate using the statistical Z test. Iterative tests revealed that Z factors of N = 50 events and T = 2 years were optimal for detecting sudden rate changes such as quiescence and to map these spatially. The observed quiescence periods conformed to the subsequent major earthquake occurrences both spatially and temporally. Using suitable conditions obtained from successive retrospective tests, the seismicity rate changes were then mapped from the most up-to-date seismicity data available. This revealed three areas along the SASZ that might generate a major earthquake in the future: (i) Nicobar Islands (Z = 6.7), (ii) the western offshore side of Sumatra Island (Z = 7.1), and (iii) western Myanmar (Z = 6.7). The performance of a stochastic test using a number of synthetic randomized catalogues indicated these levels of anomalous Z value showed the above anomaly is unlikely due to chance or random fluctuations of the earthquake. Thus, these three areas have a high possibility of generating a strong-to-major earthquake in the future.

organization.$: Morphology of Earth Surface and Advanced Geohazards in Southeast Asia Research Unit (MESA RU)
